pros: Good University, Good curriculum and placement opportunities
cons: Nothing that I felt was a huge con here

pros: Can easily study while you're on the job. You decide your own hours each semester you work. Meeting students outside your major or general friend circle.
cons: Pays little and strictly limits number of hours you can work. When I was there I earned $8/hour for 8 hours of work per week. Many times during the two years I worked there, I asked for more hours/pay, since I was tutoring for two departments at once as a double-major, but I was always told no. Overall company culture is VERY religious, white, and conservative.

review_title: Great Institution That Is Getting Stronger
pros: The people—great colleagues. The studenst—it is a privilege to teach the calibre of students who choose to come to UD.
cons: Irving isn’t the prettiest city in the US.

pros: Good benefits, superior environment among the educated

pros: Depending on what department you enter, you can work hybrid. If you're going to work here, take advantage of the tuition exchange -but then you lock yourself in till you (spouse or kids) graduate.
cons: Leadership sends the message the university doesn't have enough money. High employee turn-over and tasks get put on remaining employees without adjustment

pros: Faculty is amazing and a joy to work with. The students are respectful and great to work with.
cons: Mid level management and some directors are only in it for themselves and seem to lose track of the mission of the university.

review_title: Great University, Wonderful People, No Upward Mobility
pros: If you love Catholicism and the Liberal Arts, this is a great place to be for the mission or culture. Also, good benefits on 401k and PTO.
cons: However, the university (as stated in staff handbook) does not offer merit based raises and it can be really difficult to lobby for a promotion because of budget issues. Because of this, there is really high turnover on the staff side, which can be demoralizing.

pros: Great if you share the outlook of the management
cons: Terrible if you see things differently or are a minority.

review_title: Loved the People, Not the Environment
pros: Liked the people I worked with and meeting students
cons: team needs better structure, communication from leadership was lacking, not clear job description, no growth or willingness to help young professionals grow, not great pay

pros: Time-off; good academics; good metroplex
cons: Horrible pay; poor leadership; horrible facilities; live to work for time-off

pros: Good working environment I enjoy my time there
cons: Nothing to say about that

pros: Beautiful campus that is well kept. Many long time employees. Friendly and professional atmosphere. Great “free tuition” benefit for full-time employees & their spouse/kids (can earn a Bachelor’s or Master’s degree tuition free at UD). Offered very good medical benefits and 403b with matching funds. Enjoyed working there, only left because I got married and moved out of state.
cons: Pay for police and campus safety officers should be a bit higher to remain competitive due to the current market & shortages of police officers looking for jobs.

pros: Great community! Tip jar is nice.
cons: Outdated technology, high demand and long lines at the cap bar.

pros: Great place to work on campus, amazing staff and great environment.
cons: There are no cons to work at this place, it's an amazing place to work at.

pros: Great community among the other RAs, great support from professional staff, and while there is an occasional party, most of the time it's pretty calm as far as discipline goes. I appreciate how much we get to focus on community building.
cons: Because we're such a small school, you can sometimes get asked to do things that probably normally wouldn't fall into the RA position, but nothing too crazy and everything is still connected to residence life.

pros: All I can say is Great
cons: There are no Cons for UD

pros: Great place to work at, everyone treats you like their family member, they genuinely care about your well-being and your professional and personal growth.

review_title: Great place if you like to work in higher ed
job_title: Director Client Services in Irving, TX
pros: flexible, fun working with students.
cons: low compensation but ok if you like to work in higher ed

pros: Great people and an awesome mission
cons: Lack of material resources but not much of a problem

review_title: A great college to work for in higher education, and the students truly make your work worthwhile.
pros: I have a confidence in the leadership structure of UD, and I've seen the school make great strides in the short time working here (about 2 and 1/2 years). There are holidays for major events (Easter, Thanksgiving, etc) and generally easy flexibility when requesting vacation time - especially during the summer. Training, at least within our office, is great and hands on learning. The work environment is highly enjoyable. Not only are my coworkers pleasant to work with, more often than not, working with other departments is a friendly experience. The school is definitely on an upward trend (new building for the Satish and Yasmin Gupta College of Business, new aesthetic updates, and positive leadership, to name a few things) and I would recommend getting on board!
cons: Since the school is somewhat smaller than other universities your job responsibilities may sometimes extend beyond your primary, or even secondary, responsibilities. However, when you are tasked with those assignments you are usually recognized by your supervisor for your efforts. Some may view the compensation as lower than other universities within the area, I'd say the compensation is within range or close to par when compared to others.

pros: good working environment, friendly, silent
cons: there are no cons for this workplace

pros: The schedule was great and summers were a more casual, which was a nice change. The students are polite and enthusiastic learners. The campus is aging and there are occasional maintenance issues like power or water outages.
cons: Being Catholic is not a requirement for employment, but some staff treat non-Catholics rather rudely. My supervisor called me a heathen and sprinkled holy water on my desk and chair on a regular basis. Non-Catholic students often mentioned feeling ostracized.

review_title: great place because of the students, horrible management.
job_title: Senior Graphic Designer in Irving, TX
pros: the interns make you want to do your best and show them how management should treat them. the free 6 credit hours per semester as a bonus.
cons: high turn-over and the wrong people are hired for important positions that lack qualifications needed to do the jobs.

pros: The people. Employees are dedicated, kind, and thoughtful.
cons: Top administration sometimes sees employees as pegs to be put in holes.  Conveniently change job titles on you and ask people to move on when they are no longer of use.  Pay is not great, even amongst higher ed salaries.  Flexibility on hours is really good too.

pros: Great Professors, good curriculum. Lively and enthusiastic student body. Teachers are very involved in making sure the students understand material
cons: The Core is way too big, so it is very difficult to fit in classes you actually want to take. Also, housing requirements are very restrictive.

pros: Flexible hours. Worked with my schedule. Lot's of different job opportunities based on interests, and schedule. Bosses are accommodating for student workers and their school work.
cons: Depending on the job, minimal to zero weekend hours...certain jobs are only seasonal. HR is kind of disorganized.

review_title: UD is a good place to work
pros: University environment is very conducive to attaining higher education goals while working full time.  Opportunity to be involved in many aspects of the University operations.  Lateral moves are possible for general jobs.
cons: Limited growth due to size of this small university.

pros: Some employees are really passionate about their job.
cons: Small university..everybody knows everyone. Hard to move to other departments without your current supervisor being warned. Very low pay for the work load. Management promotes unqualified candidates from within to save money.

pros: Students are smart and challenging.  Need better excel backgrounds.
cons: I know five staff members who are actively looking and can't wait to leave.  Management doesn't communicate well, disorganized, petty.  Hints of playing to youngest, prettiest former student for new hires.  HR seems over burdened.  IT projects drag on. Don't seem to have tools to do amount of work they have.  Most are very nice people and love the students and university.

pros: Great environment with a beautiful campus secluded away from the rest of DFW and the people at UD are wonderful and friendly.
cons: There really isn't anything I can think of. Oh, wait, more summer Fridays. Those are always great.
